Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 10:32PM daisylego wrote: YAY sherry! ^5 to both of us haveing cancer free brains :) I hope you never have to be in the stage IV club :)
Posts.Title: Would you want to know? daisylego konakat

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 02:55PM daisylego wrote: Livingit: I've decided to go ahead and have the scan. If there are spots bigger than 1cm then they would be treatable. The only real problem would be if something showed up that is smaller than 1 cm. Then the only option would be to watch and wait. Of course it could end up clear. The bone scan was clear.  It's pretty much the only scan that was clear though, that is why I'm worried.
Posts.Title: Would you want to know? daisylego konakat

Posts.Content: daisylego wrote: I have a script to get a brain scan. I have no symptoms, but since these liver mets showed up out of nowhere, we were concerned enough to ask for one. The oncologist was perfectly willing to give it to me but she also warned me that if a spot shows up that is less than 1cm, it might be cancer but it is too small to biopsy so we would just have to watch and wait. Brain scans are not given unless someone is symptomatic. As far as I know I have nothing even resembling symptoms.  If it is growing in my brain right now, that is pretty much the WORST thing I can imagine. I still have the option to not get the scan. Would you? Dx 2/19/2010, IDC, Right, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/12 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 3/17/2010 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary Targeted Therapy Herceptin (trastuzumab) Surgery Prophylactic ovary removal Targeted Therapy Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Would you want to know? daisylego konakat

Posts.Content: May 17, 2010 09:46AM daisylego wrote: Thank you for all the encouraging comments! It is good to know that I have more options and if anything does show up, I can have a second opinion until I find someone who is willing to treat me. I wasn't aware that hre2+ has an increased risk of brain mets. The one person I know well with advanced breast cancer, her brain was her first metastisis and she is triple negative. She (and a very stupid doctor who did not take BC into account when treating a headache that wouldn't go away and lasted for months) waited quite a long time to get treatment even with some pretty severe symptoms. She has a significant amount of lasting brain damage from the whole expereince. As for the women who chose not to know, I can understand where they are coming from and sympathize with them, I was almost one of them. Considering I specifically asked whether or not someone would get the scan and why, I am very, very grateful to everyone for sharing their decisions and motivations with me, particularly when they may be unpopular decisions.

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 11:36AM daisylego wrote: Sherryw I have my fingers crossed for you, please do let us know how your scan comes out. For everyone who has been waiting for my results, they are CLEAR!!!!!!!!!!! YAY!!!!!!!!!!!!! I cried during the test, but it was more because I was sad, than being claustrophobic or scared of the procedure. I have had a LOT of mood swings lately. Crying, yelling, and back again in 2.5 seconds :( But I'm glad I got the scan, I'm glad I posted here too, Finding out how other people have been treated and recovered makes me feel better too. Even better is knowing that I don't have cancer in my brain! Thank you all for sharing your decisions and reasons and experiences with me :) I don't know how I would deal without this forum!
Posts.Title: Would you want to know? daisylego konakat

Posts.Content: daisylego wrote: I haven't been on here in a long time. I've been working full time and trying to get through chemo. A quick review: I found my lump on Valentine's day, diagnosed back in February, had a major lumpectomy with 1st level node dissection. This led to lymphedema. Had a routine basline scan prior to starting chemo that showed suspicious places in liver that turned out to be mets. Initial diagnosis of stage 4 at 26 years old. One was treated with radiofrequency ablation, the other was inoperable due to being located near a major vein.  I had 4 treatemtents of TCH, the last was about 2 weeks ago. The results from my mugga scan were that the Herceptin is affecting my heart and I need another scan in a few weeks to see how quickly I bounce back before they decide if I can have herceptin again. I also had a brain MRI a few days ago due to some dizzy spells I've been having lately, getting results on Monday. Hoping that it's just due to changing psych meds in preperation for starting tamoxifen. I'm really scared about the CT scan I'm going to have this week. I'm ready to start living my life again, and I feel like everything has been on hold while I've been waiting for chemo to be over. I've already discussed it with my Onc, no matter what the results, she wants me to try Tamoxifen next. I'm really looking forward to that. I've been on lupron already, so even if the menopausal symptoms get worse, I'm not anticipating it to be bad at all compared to chemo. I'm even more scared of the *next* 3 month scan. If the cancer has grown or spread at that point will I have to go back on chemo? Shortly after I was diagnosed, long before we knew I was stage 4, my boyfriend of 6 & 1/2 years (FINALLY)  proposed. I told him we would schedule it for when my hair grows back. Well now that chemo is over, I'm ready to start planning. My social worker told me I could have a pixie cut as soon as October. So I don't want to wait anymore. I want to live. And I want to get married. But what if I start planning and then I find out I need chemo again? I don't want to be a bald bride. (And I will NOT wear a wig on my wedding day. I have a very nice wig that I wear to work. Wigs have their place, but not for me, on my wedding day.) I've been thinking about next May. I want enough time to plan, but now I'm thinking again. I don't know what to do. I'm just taking one day at a time, but how do I plan a wedding taking one day at a time? Dx 2/19/2010, IDC, Right, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/12 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 3/17/2010 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary Targeted Therapy Herceptin (trastuzumab) Surgery Prophylactic ovary removal Targeted Therapy Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Wanting to live-and getting married!!! daisylego hrf

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 06:40PM daisylego wrote: I would rather be bald than wear a wig. I go bald quite a bit, I just really want my own hair for my wedding. I think I'm going to have to just go ahead. So much can happen in this time frame. And you're right, I do have to keep living my life :)
Posts.Title: Wanting to live-and getting married!!! daisylego hrf

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 08:26PM daisylego wrote: I posted all the way up at the beginning of the thread that I expected to do chemo on 4/15 but might be delayed. Turns out that I am VERY delayed. We are STILL trying to figure out whether the cancer is in my liver or not. Hopefully I will start by the end of May, but that puts me well behind all of you lovely ladies. Good luck to all of you :)

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2010 04:12PM daisylego wrote: I've been looking for this thread to start up. I was scheduled for a port on Mon & 1st dose of CTH on Thurs 4/15. I might have to reschedule though because my lumpectomy site has an infection. I'll probably still end up sometime in April though. I hope the infection clears up soon. It's already resisted the first antibiotic. (For details see "my drain is a pain" in the surgical forum!) Good luck to the ladies who've started already!

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 02:56PM daisylego wrote: 26, Thought I was stage IIb at first. Pre-chemo routine testing found liver mets. So I'm stage IV at diagnosis.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: daisylego wrote: I may or may not belong in your club now girls. I'm still waiting to find out. I had found a lump in my breast on 2/14, had surgery on 3/18 came back as 3.2cm & 3/12 nodes. Stage 2b, not what I wanted, but not too bad either. I was just starting to get to an emotional place where I can deal with that. I had taken a couple of tests to check if I am healthy enough for chemo, including a CT scan of my chest, stomach and pelvis. All routine. Imagine my shock and horror when my Onc says that there are three spots on my liver that might be cancer and I need a biopsy! (Scheduled for Monday, I should have the results by Friday at the latest.) I immediately had what my boyfriend called "a complete emotional breakdown" I don't even know how long I was sobbing and shaking. I thought if breast cancer is diagnosed at stage 4, usually it is found from symptoms in wherever else it went to besides the breast? How many of you found the lump in your breast first but were already stage 4 anyway? Also, have any of you had a liver biopsy? What is it like? I've calmed down since the breakdown at the Dr's office, but I am so freaking terrified. And a little numb. I really cannot believe this is happening. Dx 2/19/2010, IDC, Right, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/12 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 3/17/2010 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary Targeted Therapy Herceptin (trastuzumab) Surgery Prophylactic ovary removal Targeted Therapy Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 04:13AM daisylego wrote: PaintedGate: Thank you for taking the time and effort to make your first post just for me :) Knowing that you, and others like you are still going strong a year or years after diagnosis gives me hope that I did not have when I first learned that I might have cancer in my liver. Thank you also for the tip about the social worker/nurse practitioner. I have been working extensively with both at my cancer center. I don't know how I would get through this without them. They have been wonderful! I was very worried about my fertility at first, now I'm not so sure. I guess I still want to protect it, just in case I do decide to have children. I've always been so adamant about wanting kids. But the thought of leaving them without a mother is unbearable. But it is still not something I am ready to close the door on completely. The thought of being at stage IV makes me feel much less secure in my mortality. When I thought I was stage II, I could concentrate on moving past all of this as quickly as possible. Now that I might be stage IV, looking at cancer as a chronic condition is new to me. I'm so used to thinking of cancer as something that you either cure or it kills you. I'm glad that there is another option now, but it is difficult to wrap my head around.  I've decided not to go through with the second needle biopsy tomorrow morning. Now that I know it is possible to do the procedure entirely laproscopically, I want to be knocked out!!! The recovery time won't be that much worse and I'm pretty much guaranteed a definitive answer. I don't see a reason NOT to go straight to the laproscopic surgery. The only reason I didn't make this decision on friday was that I wasn't thinking clearly enough.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 10:48PM daisylego wrote: Thank you everyone, for all your supportive comments. I'm off to bed. I have to wake up early to go to the hospital. I'm glad I had that total breakdown at the dr office. I got it out of my system and now I'm just numb and scared. I think the worst part of thinking I might be stage 4 already is that I never even had a chance to fight it. Like the war is lost before the first battle. But then I might be worrying over nothing. I never thought I would be *hoping* for more fat! And I hope the biopsy results will come back quickly.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 02:39PM daisylego wrote: Well it's official now ladies. I am a member of the stage IV club. They were only able to fry one of the two suspicious spots, the other was too deep & too dangerous to treat the same way. I should be starting chemo in a little over a week. They expect the other spot to respond to chemo. After this emotional rollercoaster, I guess I'm glad to finally know. I'm glad the waiting is over. I can't even cry about it because sobbing jiggles my insides and it is agony.

Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 03:09PM daisylego wrote: No results yet of course, just rereading all the supportive comments. The liver biopsy was much worse than the breast biopsy, but I survived. Apparantly how a liver biopsy goes is entirely dependent on where in the liver they need to biopsy. The suspicious places on my scan happened to be in the most difficult to reach spot on the whole liver. Joy. They barely sedated me at all because I had to breathe deeper than I thought possible and hold my breath for as long as possible. (They could only reach the spot when my lungs were fully expanded with air, pushing my liver out from under my ribcage.) The doc & techs & nurses all said I was the best at holding my breath that they had ever seen & that is the only reason they were able to successfully reach it at all. It was also much more painful than the breast biopsy. They told me there is a inner skin over the liver which cannot be numbed, so even though the local has thoroughly numbed the surface of your skin, the needle is still painful. Imagine having to hold perfectly still and hold your breath while being kicked in the stomach. And if you don't do it right they have to try again! In some ways the waiting is easier than with the breast biopsy. I already know I have cancer. I already had a total emotional breakdown, sobbing & shaking for 2 hrs in the oncologist's office. I have much more support in place (breastcancer.org for one!) I'm mostly numb right now.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 12:33PM daisylego wrote: I asked about a PET scan, but apparantly my Onc doesn't use them for diagnostic purposes. She said if it came back positive then they would still need to confirm with a biopsy and if it came back negative they would still need a biopsy to be sure, so I should just do the biopsy. What did your liver lesions end up being? Did they do blood tests for you? They haven't done any extra blood tests for me. Anyway I'm having surgery on Monday to put a port in. So I get more poking & prodding. Yay :(
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 10:47PM daisylego wrote: Thank you all for your support! What would I do without you?!?! Drive myself even crazier most likely :/ I feel more in control today. I took things out of the hands of just the oncologist (which I am starting to have some very mixed feelings about) today. I saw my primary and she sent me to a gastrointerologist, which was SOOOO incredibly helpful!!! I now am getting some tumor marker tests done (finally!) and I also now have a MUCH better idea of my diagnostic options. (and the pros & cons of a few of my choices) I am convinced that I absolutely do need to know if this is cancer or not, and I have accepted the need for it. My oncologist also set me up with a liver surgeon who I'm having a consultation with tomorrow afternoon. I also meet my radiologic oncologist tomorrow, so a pretty busy day.  I did not like my oncologist's attitude when I told her that I was seeing a gastrointerologist. She said something like "I don't know why you are bothering with that, they won't be able to do anything for you anyway, but if it makes you feel better, go right ahead, I have no objection" She also had a less than stellar attitude when I asked her about getting a second opinion ("it's really only necessary if you doubt your team")  The oncologist is also not great at getting me test results back in a prompt manner. It doesn't help that my entire household has exploded with health problems recently. Besides what is going on with me, my boyfriend has a very bad case of poision ivy, some possible chemical burns in a tender area due to his attempts to treat this (makes for a VERY cranky boyfriend!) AND the relative of his that lives with us & we take care of has just come down with shingles!!! Knock wood that nothing ELSE goes wrong! Anyway, I'll post again when I know more, possibly tomorrow night if I'm up to it. For now it's a nice soak in the bath & then SLEEP! *big hugs* to everyone who has posted here! It's a very good feeling to know you care!
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 03:42PM daisylego wrote: They didn't tell me anti inflamitories, but I didn't decline pain meds. I'm fairly comfortable right now though. Thank you for your prayers! I need all the help I can get!
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2010 06:55PM daisylego wrote: I got the results: Non diagnostic sample, more tests needed! AAACCCCCKKKKKK!!!!!! They're going to try to get more info from the sample that they already took, but if they still aren't sure then I get to do the damn biopsy AGAIN. If they still don't know then they have to do a surgical biopsy. I'm left wondering how important is it to know for sure? We seem to be going to a lot of trouble to figure this out. We already know I have cancer, what else can we do about it? Will it change anything? These are questions for my Onc the next time I see her & before I schedule any other procedures.  Oy Vey.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 11:59PM daisylego wrote: Just an update to let you all know that I haven't forgotten about you, I just still have no answer. Hopefully the answer will be in by tomorrow though, so that is very exciting. Even better is the second opinion liver surgeon who can diagnose me without surgery!!! He has a very strong background in liver tumors of all kinds and he is pretty confidant that it is *not* metastatic breast cancer. I have heard simmilar before. (About the initial breast lump). But I trust his experience and I don't think he is just saying it to make me feel better. He says that if it is the type of non cancerous tumor that he thinks it is, then a simple MRI will be diagnostic to prove it with 99% certainty. YAY! No more painful procedures!  I was just starting to gear up and get started fighting this thing. I was even seriously considering cold cap treatment to try to keep my hair. I guess I was just looking for ways to make this whole thing a little more bearable. And then out of left field I get hit with this sucker punch. Suddenly I'm more concerned about whether I'm going to live or die than I am about my hair. I guess it put things in perspective for me. Hopefully I can come out of this liver scare (and I hope it is just a scare) with a lesson. I was feeling pretty sorry for myself about having node positive stage two cancer, until I *truly* understood how much worse it could be. While I'm still not sure if I believe that there is a higher power that can or would be sending me this message, I can still take it as a lesson anyway. Hopefully I will have the MRI results by tomorrow. After seeing the second opinion surgeon, I am really truly hopeful that these liver masses will turn out to be benign. I will post again when I know for sure.   A big thank you to all you wonderful ladies that have given me so much support over the past couple of weeks. It feels like more, it feels like forever.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 10:36PM daisylego wrote: EnglishMajor: the only whole body test I had pre-surgery was a bone scan. And that might only be because I was complaining of some soreness. I had the whole variety of breast scans. Ultrasound & Mammo. Then biopsy. Then Breast MRI & genetic marker test. Then the surgery. Then decided on which chemo I needed & was planning the port insertion surgery when I had the Mugga scan and the CT. Postponing chemo because of an infection due to some infection from my surgery. (see "my drain is a pain" for more about that!) Darlinedenise: I do have an anti-anxiety perscription. I didn't have it at the dr's office so they had to find one for me. They said they were going to do one through IV if they couldnt find a pill! Thanks for sharing your story with me. Are the tumor markers part of your bloodwork? As far as I know, all my bloodwork had come back clean. Everyone, thank you for responding. I'm more scared than I have ever been about anything ever. And I feel like I can't talk to anyone about it because I don't want my close friends and family to be scared too. My mom knows I'm hiding something from her and I feel bad about that. I know she'll understand. My boyfriend does know, he was there with me at the dr office.  I will update here when I have the news, sometime later this week. I'm supposed to know by friday at the latest. I have no idea how I will deal until then.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 08:34PM daisylego wrote: MRI results are in. It looks like it probably IS metastatic breast cancer. 2nd opinion liver surgeon was ready to leave it at that, but my oncologist demands tissue proof before we call it for sure. Second needle biopsy on Monday. 2nd opinion liver surgeon will also get the actual images on Monday. If the second needle biopsy is also inconclusive, then I will have 2nd liver surgeon do laproscopic surgery. First liver surgeon would have done "hand assisted laproscopic surgery" more invasive, more scarring and more recovery time. I am so sick of this roller coaster.
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 10:28PM daisylego wrote: I guess I am calmer. Deciding not to have that next needle biopsy was a HUGE step in asserting my rights as a patient and making a powerful treatment decision for myself. I feel just one tiny bit less like I am on a runaway rollercoaster. I guess I haven't made such an important decision for myself since picking which breast surgery I would have. Having these spots in my liver has taken so much time. I can see the light at the end of the tunnel now. I just can't tell if it is sunshine or an oncoming train. But either way I can see the end of this uncertainty. I will know on Thursday. Either way, my wait will be over. Anyway, I need to get some rest, I'm going to work tomorrow!
Posts.Title: Initial diagnosis of stage IV? daisylego redskies

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 03:08AM daisylego wrote: I've got my second treatment tomorrow. I'm almost more scared this time even though it wasn't so bad last time and the docs all said it will be simmilar every time. Maybe I wonder if it was worse than my memory of it. My hair is falling out fast now. I have to pick up my wig that I ordered before it all goes. I had a haircut on Monday, it's now above my ears. It had been well below my shoulders. It feels strange.

You'll have a wonderful time at Hershey I'm sure! I thought maybe you live near me when you said that was where you were going :) Leanna: I'd tell you I'll be thinking about you too, but I'll probably be asleep for most of it, one of the first few things they give me is benadryl :)  Maybe I'm crazy but I'm actually planning on going out to a party/club thing Friday night with my boyfriend. I'm guessing that I'll be feeling pretty good from all the pre-meds, but I'm still wondering if I've gone nutters :)
Posts.Title: May 2010 Chemo fotopet leftduetostupidmods

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 09:00PM daisylego wrote: Well my treatment was worse than last time but not awful. Knowing what to expect made it better but tweaking the premeds needs work. Giving me oral benadryl to make me less dopey and then IV adivan to make me more dopey? Does not compute.  I ended up feeling doped up but being awake for more of it, and cranky.  I'm highly doubting the wisdom of doing so much tomorrow. We'll see how I feel I guess. Leanna: I hope your treatment went as well or better than mine and I hope your neulasta tomorrow goes easy. I just had pain when they injected me and then mild bone pain last time. Hopefully  this will be no different.
Posts.Title: May 2010 Chemo fotopet leftduetostupidmods

Posts.Content: daisylego wrote: I was talking with my Your Shoes network of strength volunteer match a couple of days ago about my chemo and she thought there would be other ladies on here that could benefit from a treatment for nausea that I've been using. Sea bands work from pressure points on the wrist. I have horrible motion sickness, and discovered these were helpful for that. (I was quite skeptical at first but tried them when I was desperate and was shocked by how well they worked.) Now I'm using them for chemo. No chemicals, no side effects. Anyone at risk from or experienceing lymphedema (like me) should be careful about using them on the affected wrist. When I was using them for motion sickness, I found that they only worked when they were on both wrists correctly (the little white bead needs to be in a very specific spot, but the included directions make that relatively easy). Now I find they work if I put it on just my non-lymphedema arm. I have some swelling in my surgical wrist so I don't know if that is putting pressure on the same spot in a different way. My guess is that someone with no swelling but a risk for future swelling needs to use them on both wrists. As always, ask your doc. But if someone is looking for a natural remedy for nausea, which can be layered over all your other nausea meds this is a very good thing to try. I hope it helps some of you as much as it helped me!  I find it works within 5 min, but when you take it off, it stops working within 5 min as well. I'd be more surprised if you didn't cry. I was watching a video of BC survivors speaking to patients and every time they said "it's OK to cry" I started bawling.
